review.title: New Limits for Knowledge Compilation and Applications to Exact Model Counting
review.abstract: We show new limits on the efficiency of using current techniques to make exact probabilistic inference for large classes of natural problems. In particular we show new lower bounds on knowledge compilation to SDD and DNNF forms. We give strong lower bounds on the complexity of SDD representations by relating SDD size to best-partition communication complexity. We use this relationship to prove exponential lower bounds on the SDD size for representing a large class of problems that occur naturally as queries over probabilistic databases. A consequence is that for representing unions of conjunctive queries, SDDs are not qualitatively more concise than OBDDs. We also derive simple examples for which SDDs must be exponentially less concise than FBDDs. Finally, we derive exponential lower bounds on the sizes of DNNF representations using a new quasipolynomial simulation of DNNFs by nondeterministic FBDDs.
histories: Full version of paper to appear at UAI 2015
Full version of paper appearing UAI 2015 updated to include new references to related work
review.COMMENTS: Full version of paper to appear at UAI 2015

sections.heading: 3 SDDs and Best-Partition Communication Complexity
sections.text: In this section, we will show how to use any small SDD that represents a function f to create an efficient communication protocol for f for an approximately balanced partition of input variables determined by the associated vtree. As a result, any function that requires large communication complexity among all these partitions requires large SDDs. At the beginning of this analysis, we will look at how an SDD simplifies when partially mapped to its input variables.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: We have made the first significant progress in understanding the complexity of general DND representations. We have also created a new link between the SDD representations and the best partition communication complexity. The lowest rate for OBDD size is 2C and the lowest rate we have shown for SDD size. This is a quasi-polynomial difference and corresponds to the quasi-polynomial separation between OBDD and SDD size.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements

sections.heading: A Proof of Theorem 3.6
sections.text: Let f (A, B) be a function with unique communication complexity g = and let Mf be its communication matrix. Then, there is a row D of 2g disjunct monochromatic rectangles that cover the 1s of Mf. Let G be a graph whose nodes are the rectangles in D and which has an edge that connects two rectangles when they share a row of Mf. Then, each row r of Mf (r, c) corresponds to a clique Kr that intersects the rectangles. Likewise, each column c corresponds to an independent row Ic that intersects the rectangles. Finally, we note that [Razgon, 2014] showed that SDDs can be powerful by finding examples where OBDDs using any order are quasipolynomially less concise than SDDs.
This is a quasipolynomial difference and matches the quasipolynomial separation between OBDD and SDD size shown in [Razgon, 2014].

metadata.abstractText: We show new limits on the efficiency of using current techniques to make exact probabilistic inference for large classes of natural problems. In particular we show new lower bounds on knowledge compilation to SDD and DNNF forms. We give strong lower bounds on the complexity of SDD representations by relating SDD size to best-partition communication complexity. We use this relationship to prove exponential lower bounds on the SDD size for representing a large class of problems that occur naturally as queries over probabilistic databases. A consequence is that for representing unions of conjunctive queries, SDDs are not qualitatively more concise than OBDDs. We also derive simple examples for which SDDs must be exponentially less concise than FBDDs. Finally, we derive exponential lower bounds on the sizes of DNNF representations using a new quasipolynomial simulation of DNNFs by nondeterministic FBDDs.
